Cedric, I think it=
 is good to think about testing in planning phase. I
guess for a team new t=
o JUnit-based testing, the productivity will be
decreased at the begining. =

<cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> Fascinating questions, Frank :-)
> 
> A few thought=
s.
> 
> 
>    - Will thorough testing make the project take longer?  Of cou=
rse it
>    will.  Either in time or in programmers.  After all, we are
tal=
king about
>    writing more code, so the number of man.months is going to =
go up as
>    well.
> 
>    The way to solve this problem is to include tes=
ting in the planning
>    and project features and deadlines accordingly, b=
ut for having
been there as
>    well, I agree that it's not always possibl=
e.
> 
>    - Using debuggers less might be a good thing *if* the developers=
 find
>    bugs faster.  I have seen quite a few TDD enthusiasts choose not=

to use
>    debuggers for dogmatic reasons ("because I read it in a book")=

and then
>    spend hours writing tests or even println's trying to reprod=
uce a
mysterious
>    bug that a breakpoint would have caught in a few minu=
tes.
> 
>    Again, the solution here is to be pragmatic:  you have two too=
ls at
>    your disposal (testing and debugger), both with their pros and
c=
ons, and
>    you'd be a fool to choose to use only one.
> 
> --
